text: I grew up with a saying that my
grandfather used to say all the time and
that's people protect what they loved my
father followed that up recently with
how can people protect what they don't
understand well you know out of sight
out of mind doesn't work anymore because
luckily for us technology has caught up
to a point where all of us can be
informed and should be informed so that
we can make better decisions in our
everyday lives and i think that's that's
really one of the wonderful things and
we're the only creatures on the planet
who can do that then you can see all
these poor creatures in the Gulf they
realize that there's trouble out there
they don't know why and they don't know
what to do about it you know I know why
I am your princess fish could scream yes
you know I think very different to
follow up on that you know I Eddie chase
Joe he says I could scream we think
differently about them you know i miss a
mystery grandfather and I miss having
that sort of passion splash across my
television screen every week that was
something you know amazingly powerful
that we don't have today when I go up to
these schools around the country
ninety-five percent of kids I take a
hand poll ninety-five percent of these
kids are watching Deadliest Catch and
about the same or watching shark week
they love the oceans even the ones that
have never seen an ocean but they're as
terrified as the ocean as they are in
love with it and I think a lot of this
does have to do with the media that we
are consuming as human beings we have to
see something that is a more realistic
and positive and passionate voice for
the ocean we do worry that after the oil
spill gets you know eventually the media
is going to tire of it it's perfect you
know you've got a villain BP you've got
the oil which is ugly you've got the oil
soap birds the impact on humanity things
like from our everyday lives that are
threat to the sea flame retardants that
are in all these fabrics and
electronics mounts up deadly deadly
stuffer to see plastics deadly stuff for
the sea comes back to us when we eat
seafood yep yeah we're in our own bodies
we were seeing toxic levels of
herbicides pesticides fungicides
pharmaceuticals all the things that we
do you know it comes to the ocean in
that beautiful crystal clear water that
comes out of our fields and and washes
off of our farmlands and our backyards
that stuff brings death to the sea in
some cases and but it's not an event you
know there's no villain it's everybody
so there are certain things that we're
going to have to we need to take a deep
breath not panic and get get some
leadership and get on a course of action
and I think what we find is that a lot
of the little things got us in this
trouble that we started to do it may be
a lot of the little things that we pull
together will get us out of it in the
long run
